verses.translation: They will cry, “I wish I had sent forth ˹something good˺ for my ˹true˺ life.”

verses.text: On that Day He will punish ˹them˺ severely, like no other,
verses.translation: On that Day He will punish ˹them˺ severely, like no other,

verses.text: and bind ˹them˺ tightly, like no other.[1310] Good News for the Faithful
verses.translation: and bind ˹them˺ tightly, like no other.[1310] Good News for the Faithful

verses.text: ˹Allah will say to the righteous,˺ “O tranquil soul!
verses.translation: ˹Allah will say to the righteous,˺ “O tranquil soul!

verses.text: Return to your Lord, well pleased ˹with Him˺ and well pleasing ˹to Him˺.
verses.translation: Return to your Lord, well pleased ˹with Him˺ and well pleasing ˹to Him˺.

verses.text: So join My servants,
verses.translation: So join My servants,

verses.text: and enter My Paradise.” *** -- 548 of 694 --
verses.translation: and enter My Paradise.” *** -- 548 of 694 --

name: The City
intro: The underlying theme of this Meccan sûrah is that human beings are equipped with the necessary faculties to choose between right and wrong. The good-doers are promised Paradise and the evildoers are promised Hell. This theme is emphasized in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Ungrateful Disbelievers

verses.text: I do swear by this city ˹of Mecca˺—
verses.translation: I do swear by this city ˹of Mecca˺—

verses.text: even though you ˹O Prophet˺ are subject to abuse in this city—
verses.translation: even though you ˹O Prophet˺ are subject to abuse in this city—

verses.text: and by every parent and ˹their˺ child!
verses.translation: and by every parent and ˹their˺ child!

verses.text: Indeed, We have created humankind in ˹constant˺ struggle.
verses.translation: Indeed, We have created humankind in ˹constant˺ struggle.

verses.text: Do they think that no one has power over them,
verses.translation: Do they think that no one has power over them,

verses.text: boasting, “I have wasted enormous wealth!”?
verses.translation: boasting, “I have wasted enormous wealth!”?

verses.text: Do they think that no one sees them?
verses.translation: Do they think that no one sees them?

verses.text: Have We not given them two eyes,
verses.translation: Have We not given them two eyes,

verses.text: a tongue, and two lips;
verses.translation: a tongue, and two lips;

verses.text: and shown them the two ways ˹of right and wrong˺? The Challenging Path of Good
verses.translation: and shown them the two ways ˹of right and wrong˺? The Challenging Path of Good

verses.text: If only they had attempted the challenging path ˹of goodness instead˺!
verses.translation: If only they had attempted the challenging path ˹of goodness instead˺!

verses.text: And what will make you realize what ˹attempting˺ the challenging path is?
verses.translation: And what will make you realize what ˹attempting˺ the challenging path is?

verses.text: It is to free a slave,
verses.translation: It is to free a slave,

verses.text: or to give food in times of famine
verses.translation: or to give food in times of famine

verses.text: to an orphaned relative
verses.translation: to an orphaned relative

verses.text: or to a poor person in distress,
verses.translation: or to a poor person in distress,

verses.text: and—above all—to be one of those who have faith and urge each other to perseverance and urge each other to compassion.
verses.translation: and—above all—to be one of those who have faith and urge each other to perseverance and urge each other to compassion.

verses.text: These are the people of the right.
verses.translation: These are the people of the right.

verses.text: As for those who deny Our signs, they are the people of the left.[1311]
verses.translation: As for those who deny Our signs, they are the people of the left.[1311]

verses.text: The Fire will be sealed over them. *** -- 549 of 694 --
verses.translation: The Fire will be sealed over them. *** -- 549 of 694 --

name: The Sun
intro: This Meccan sûrah states that people have free choice to purify or corrupt their souls. Those who choose purity will be successful, and those who choose corruption will be destroyed like the people of Thamûd. Free choice is the highlight of the next sûrah as well. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Purifying and Corrupting the Soul

verses.text: By the sun and its brightness,
verses.translation: By the sun and its brightness,

verses.text: and the moon as it follows it,[1312]
verses.translation: and the moon as it follows it,[1312]

verses.text: and the day as it unveils it,
verses.translation: and the day as it unveils it,

verses.text: and the night as it conceals it!
verses.translation: and the night as it conceals it!

verses.text: And by heaven and ˹the One˺ Who built it,
verses.translation: And by heaven and ˹the One˺ Who built it,

verses.text: and the earth and ˹the One˺ Who spread it!
verses.translation: and the earth and ˹the One˺ Who spread it!

verses.text: And by the soul and ˹the One˺ Who fashioned it,
verses.translation: And by the soul and ˹the One˺ Who fashioned it,

verses.text: then with ˹the knowledge of˺ right and wrong inspired it!
verses.translation: then with ˹the knowledge of˺ right and wrong inspired it!

verses.text: Successful indeed is the one who purifies their soul,
verses.translation: Successful indeed is the one who purifies their soul,

verses.text: and doomed is the one who corrupts it! Destruction of the People of Ṣâli ḥ
verses.translation: and doomed is the one who corrupts it! Destruction of the People of Ṣâli ḥ

verses.text: Thamûd rejected ˹the truth˺ out of arrogance,
verses.translation: Thamûd rejected ˹the truth˺ out of arrogance,

verses.text: when the most wicked of them was roused ˹to kill the she-camel˺.
verses.translation: when the most wicked of them was roused ˹to kill the she-camel˺.

verses.text: But the messenger of Allah warned them, “˹Do not disturb˺ Allah’s camel and her ˹turn to˺ drink!”
verses.translation: But the messenger of Allah warned them, “˹Do not disturb˺ Allah’s camel and her ˹turn to˺ drink!”

verses.text: Still they defied him and slaughtered her. So their Lord crushed them for their crime, levelling all to the ground.[1313]
verses.translation: Still they defied him and slaughtered her. So their Lord crushed them for their crime, levelling all to the ground.[1313]

verses.text: He has no fear of consequences. *** -- 550 of 694 --
verses.translation: He has no fear of consequences. *** -- 550 of 694 --

name: The Night
intro: This Meccan sûrah emphasizes Allah’s power to create and show the Way, the people’s ability to choose between good and evil, and the consequences of each route. The fact that the believers will be rewarded to their satisfaction is highlighted in this sûrah (verse 21) and the next (93:5). In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful The Faithful and the Faithless

verses.text: By the night when it covers,
verses.translation: By the night when it covers,

verses.text: and the day when it shines!
verses.translation: and the day when it shines!

verses.text: And by ˹the One˺ Who created male and female!
verses.translation: And by ˹the One˺ Who created male and female!

verses.text: Surely the ends you strive for are diverse.
verses.translation: Surely the ends you strive for are diverse.

verses.text: As for the one who is charitable, mindful ˹of Allah˺,
verses.translation: As for the one who is charitable, mindful ˹of Allah˺,

verses.text: and ˹firmly˺ believes in the finest reward,
verses.translation: and ˹firmly˺ believes in the finest reward,

verses.text: We will facilitate for them the Way of Ease.
verses.translation: We will facilitate for them the Way of Ease.

verses.text: And as for the one who is stingy, indifferent ˹to Allah˺,
verses.translation: And as for the one who is stingy, indifferent ˹to Allah˺,

verses.text: and ˹staunchly˺ denies the finest reward,
verses.translation: and ˹staunchly˺ denies the finest reward,

verses.text: We will facilitate for them the path of hardship.
verses.translation: We will facilitate for them the path of hardship.

verses.text: And their wealth will be of no benefit to them when they tumble ˹into Hell˺. Reward of the Righteous and the Wicked
verses.translation: And their wealth will be of no benefit to them when they tumble ˹into Hell˺. Reward of the Righteous and the Wicked

verses.text: It is certainly upon Us ˹alone˺ to show ˹the way to˺ guidance.
verses.translation: It is certainly upon Us ˹alone˺ to show ˹the way to˺ guidance.

verses.text: And surely to Us ˹alone˺ belong this life and the next.
verses.translation: And surely to Us ˹alone˺ belong this life and the next.

verses.text: And so I have warned you of a raging Fire,
verses.translation: And so I have warned you of a raging Fire,

verses.text: in which none will burn except the most wretched —
verses.translation: in which none will burn except the most wretched —

verses.text: who deny and turn away.
verses.translation: who deny and turn away.

verses.text: But the righteous will be spared from it —
verses.translation: But the righteous will be spared from it —

verses.text: who donate ˹some of˺ their wealth only to purify themselves,
verses.translation: who donate ˹some of˺ their wealth only to purify themselves,

verses.text: not in return for someone’s favours,
verses.translation: not in return for someone’s favours,

verses.text: but seeking the pleasure of their Lord, the Most High.
verses.translation: but seeking the pleasure of their Lord, the Most High.

verses.text: They will certainly be pleased. *** -- 551 of 694 --
verses.translation: They will certainly be pleased. *** -- 551 of 694 --

name: The Morning Sunlight
intro: It is reported that the revelation stopped for a while after the initial sûrahs of the Quran, so some Meccan pagans started to mock the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص), saying that Allah has become neglectful and hateful of him ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص). Therefore, this Meccan sûrah was revealed to refute their false allegations and remind the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) of some of Allah’s favours. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Reassuring the Prophet

verses.text: By the morning sunlight,
verses.translation: By the morning sunlight,

verses.text: and the night when it falls still!
verses.translation: and the night when it falls still!

verses.text: Your Lord ˹O Prophet˺ has not abandoned you, nor has He become hateful ˹of you˺.
verses.translation: Your Lord ˹O Prophet˺ has not abandoned you, nor has He become hateful ˹of you˺.

verses.text: And the next life is certainly far better for you than this one.
verses.translation: And the next life is certainly far better for you than this one.

verses.text: And ˹surely˺ your Lord will give so much to you that you will be pleased.
verses.translation: And ˹surely˺ your Lord will give so much to you that you will be pleased.

verses.text: Did He not find you as an orphan then sheltered you?
verses.translation: Did He not find you as an orphan then sheltered you?

verses.text: Did He not find you unguided then guided you?
verses.translation: Did He not find you unguided then guided you?

verses.text: And did He not find you needy then satisfied your needs?
verses.translation: And did He not find you needy then satisfied your needs?

verses.text: So do not oppress the orphan,
verses.translation: So do not oppress the orphan,

verses.text: nor repulse the beggar.[1314]
verses.translation: nor repulse the beggar.[1314]

verses.text: And proclaim the blessings of your Lord. *** -- 552 of 694 --
verses.translation: And proclaim the blessings of your Lord. *** -- 552 of 694 --

name: Uplifting the Heart
intro: Like the previous sûrah, this sûrah reminds the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) of more blessings to reassure him of Allah’s continued support in the city of Mecca, which is mentioned in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful More Reassurance to the Prophet

verses.text: Have We not uplifted your heart for you ˹O Prophet˺,
verses.translation: Have We not uplifted your heart for you ˹O Prophet˺,

verses.text: relieved you of the burden
verses.translation: relieved you of the burden

verses.text: which weighed so heavily on your back,
verses.translation: which weighed so heavily on your back,

verses.text: and elevated your renown for you?[1315]
verses.translation: and elevated your renown for you?[1315]

verses.text: So, surely with hardship comes ease.
verses.translation: So, surely with hardship comes ease.

verses.text: Surely with ˹that˺ hardship comes ˹more˺ ease.[1316]
verses.translation: Surely with ˹that˺ hardship comes ˹more˺ ease.[1316]

verses.text: So once you have fulfilled ˹your duty˺, strive ˹in devotion˺,
verses.translation: So once you have fulfilled ˹your duty˺, strive ˹in devotion˺,

verses.text: turning to your Lord ˹alone˺ with hope. *** -- 553 of 694 --
verses.translation: turning to your Lord ˹alone˺ with hope. *** -- 553 of 694 --

name: The Fig
intro: This Meccan sûrah emphasizes that Allah honours humans but many of them debase themselves by denying the meeting with Him in the Hereafter. Abu Jahl, one of the most notorious deniers is referred to in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Reward of Ungrateful Deniers

verses.text: By the fig and the olive ˹of Jerusalem˺,
verses.translation: By the fig and the olive ˹of Jerusalem˺,

verses.text: and Mount Sinai,
verses.translation: and Mount Sinai,

verses.text: and this secure city ˹of Mecca˺![1317]
verses.translation: and this secure city ˹of Mecca˺![1317]

verses.text: Indeed, We created humans in the best form.
verses.translation: Indeed, We created humans in the best form.

verses.text: But We will reduce them to the lowest of the low ˹in Hell˺,
verses.translation: But We will reduce them to the lowest of the low ˹in Hell˺,

verses.text: except those who believe and do good—they will have a never-ending reward.
verses.translation: except those who believe and do good—they will have a never-ending reward.

verses.text: Now, what makes you deny the ˹final˺ Judgment?
verses.translation: Now, what makes you deny the ˹final˺ Judgment?

verses.text: Is Allah not the most just of all judges? *** -- 554 of 694 --
verses.translation: Is Allah not the most just of all judges? *** -- 554 of 694 --

name: The Clinging Clot ˹of Blood˺
intro: Verses 1-5 are known to be the first ever revealed of the Quran. The Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) was retreating at a cave in the outskirts of Mecca when the angel Gabriel appeared to him, squeezing him tightly and ordering him to read. Since the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) was unlettered, he responded, “I cannot read.” Ultimately, Gabriel taught him: “Read in the Name of your Lord …” Some scholars believe that this encounter is the fulfilment of Isaiah 29:12, which states, “Then the book will be given to the one who is illiterate, saying, ‘Read this.’ And he will say, ‘I cannot read.’”[1318] The rest of the sûrah was later revealed to deter Abu Jahl, a Meccan pagan elite, from abusing the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص). In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful The First Revelation

verses.text: Read, ˹O Prophet,˺ in the Name of your Lord Who created—
verses.translation: Read, ˹O Prophet,˺ in the Name of your Lord Who created—

verses.text: created humans from a clinging clot.[1319]
verses.translation: created humans from a clinging clot.[1319]

verses.text: Read! And your Lord is the Most Generous,
verses.translation: Read! And your Lord is the Most Generous,

verses.text: Who taught by the pen—
verses.translation: Who taught by the pen—

verses.text: taught humanity what they knew not. The Man Who Abused the Prophet
verses.translation: taught humanity what they knew not. The Man Who Abused the Prophet

verses.text: Most certainly, one exceeds all bounds
verses.translation: Most certainly, one exceeds all bounds

verses.text: once they think they are self- sufficient.
verses.translation: once they think they are self- sufficient.

verses.text: ˹But˺ surely to your Lord is the return ˹of all˺.
verses.translation: ˹But˺ surely to your Lord is the return ˹of all˺.

verses.text: Have you seen the man who prevents
verses.translation: Have you seen the man who prevents

verses.text: a servant ˹of Ours˺ from praying?[1320]
verses.translation: a servant ˹of Ours˺ from praying?[1320]

verses.text: What if this ˹servant˺ is ˹rightly˺ guided,
verses.translation: What if this ˹servant˺ is ˹rightly˺ guided,

verses.text: or encourages righteousness?
verses.translation: or encourages righteousness?

verses.text: What if that ˹man˺ persists in denial and turns away?
verses.translation: What if that ˹man˺ persists in denial and turns away?

verses.text: Does he not know that Allah sees ˹all˺?
verses.translation: Does he not know that Allah sees ˹all˺?

verses.text: But no! If he does not desist, We will certainly drag him by the forelock—
verses.translation: But no! If he does not desist, We will certainly drag him by the forelock—

verses.text: a lying, sinful forelock.[1321]
verses.translation: a lying, sinful forelock.[1321]

verses.text: So let him call his associates.
verses.translation: So let him call his associates.

verses.text: We will call the wardens of Hell.
verses.translation: We will call the wardens of Hell.

verses.text: Again, no! Never obey him ˹O Prophet˺! Rather, ˹continue to˺ prostrate and draw near ˹to Allah˺. *** -- 555 of 694 --
verses.translation: Again, no! Never obey him ˹O Prophet˺! Rather, ˹continue to˺ prostrate and draw near ˹to Allah˺. *** -- 555 of 694 --

name: The Night of Glory
intro: Since the previous sûrah commemorates the first revelation, this Meccan sûrah celebrates the glorious night the Quran was revealed, which is believed to be the night of Rama ḍân 27, 610 C.E. The reason why the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) was sent with the Quran is spelled out in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful The Night the Quran Was Revealed

verses.text: Indeed, ˹it is˺ We ˹Who˺ sent this ˹Quran˺ down on the Night of Glory. [1322]
verses.translation: Indeed, ˹it is˺ We ˹Who˺ sent this ˹Quran˺ down on the Night of Glory. [1322]

verses.text: And what will make you realize what the Night of Glory is?
verses.translation: And what will make you realize what the Night of Glory is?

verses.text: The Night of Glory is better than a thousand months.
verses.translation: The Night of Glory is better than a thousand months.

verses.text: That night the angels and the ˹holy˺ spirit[1323] descend, by the permission of their Lord, for every ˹decreed˺ matter.
verses.translation: That night the angels and the ˹holy˺ spirit[1323] descend, by the permission of their Lord, for every ˹decreed˺ matter.

verses.text: It is all peace until the break of dawn. *** -- 556 of 694 --
verses.translation: It is all peace until the break of dawn. *** -- 556 of 694 --

name: The Clear Proof
intro: According to this Medinian sûrah, the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) was sent so the disbelievers may change their ways and devote their worship to Allah alone. Those who believe are promised a great reward, whereas those who persist in disbelief are warned of a horrible punishment. The judgment of the believers and disbelievers is the highlight of the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful The Prophet Is the Clear Proof

verses.text: The disbelievers from the People of the Book and the polytheists were not going to desist ˹from disbelief˺ until the clear proof came to them:
verses.translation: The disbelievers from the People of the Book and the polytheists were not going to desist ˹from disbelief˺ until the clear proof came to them:

verses.text: a messenger from Allah, reciting scrolls of ˹utmost˺ purity,
verses.translation: a messenger from Allah, reciting scrolls of ˹utmost˺ purity,

verses.text: containing upright commandments.
verses.translation: containing upright commandments.

verses.text: It was not until this clear proof came to the People of the Book that they became divided ˹about his prophethood˺—
verses.translation: It was not until this clear proof came to the People of the Book that they became divided ˹about his prophethood˺—

verses.text: even though they were only commanded to worship Allah ˹alone˺ with sincere devotion to Him in all uprightness, establish prayer, and pay alms- tax. That is the upright Way. Fate of the Deniers
verses.translation: even though they were only commanded to worship Allah ˹alone˺ with sincere devotion to Him in all uprightness, establish prayer, and pay alms- tax. That is the upright Way. Fate of the Deniers

verses.text: Indeed, those who disbelieve from the People of the Book and the polytheists will be in the Fire of Hell, to stay there forever. They are the worst of ˹all˺ beings. Fate of the Believers
verses.translation: Indeed, those who disbelieve from the People of the Book and the polytheists will be in the Fire of Hell, to stay there forever. They are the worst of ˹all˺ beings. Fate of the Believers

verses.text: Indeed, those who believe and do good—they are the best of ˹all˺ beings.
verses.translation: Indeed, those who believe and do good—they are the best of ˹all˺ beings.

verses.text: Their reward with their Lord will be Gardens of Eternity, under which rivers flow, to stay there for ever and ever. Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him. This is ˹only˺ for those in awe of their Lord. *** -- 557 of 694 --
verses.translation: Their reward with their Lord will be Gardens of Eternity, under which rivers flow, to stay there for ever and ever. Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him. This is ˹only˺ for those in awe of their Lord. *** -- 557 of 694 --

name: The ˹Ultimate˺ Quake
intro: This Medinian sûrah states that all deeds will be brought to light and accounted for on Judgment Day, which is also emphasized in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Horrors of Judgment Day

verses.text: When the earth is shaken ˹in˺ its ultimate quaking,
verses.translation: When the earth is shaken ˹in˺ its ultimate quaking,

verses.text: and when the earth throws out ˹all˺ its contents,[1324]
verses.translation: and when the earth throws out ˹all˺ its contents,[1324]

verses.text: and humanity cries, “What is wrong with it?”—
verses.translation: and humanity cries, “What is wrong with it?”—

verses.text: on that Day the earth will recount everything,
verses.translation: on that Day the earth will recount everything,

verses.text: having been inspired by your Lord ˹to do so˺.
verses.translation: having been inspired by your Lord ˹to do so˺.

verses.text: On that Day people will proceed in separate groups[1325] to be shown ˹the consequences of˺ their deeds.
verses.translation: On that Day people will proceed in separate groups[1325] to be shown ˹the consequences of˺ their deeds.

verses.text: So whoever does an atom’s weight of good will see it.
verses.translation: So whoever does an atom’s weight of good will see it.

verses.text: And whoever does an atom’s weight of evil will see it. *** -- 558 of 694 --
verses.translation: And whoever does an atom’s weight of evil will see it. *** -- 558 of 694 --

name: The Galloping ˹Horses˺
intro: This Meccan sûrah stresses the fact that people will be accountable on Judgment Day for their ingratitude to their Lord. The scene of the people emerging from their graves (verse 9) is elaborated upon in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Human Ingratitude

verses.text: By the galloping, panting horses,
verses.translation: By the galloping, panting horses,

verses.text: striking sparks of fire ˹with their hoofs˺,
verses.translation: striking sparks of fire ˹with their hoofs˺,

verses.text: launching raids at dawn,
verses.translation: launching raids at dawn,

verses.text: stirring up ˹clouds of˺ dust,
verses.translation: stirring up ˹clouds of˺ dust,

verses.text: and penetrating into the heart of enemy lines!
verses.translation: and penetrating into the heart of enemy lines!

verses.text: Surely humankind is ungrateful to their Lord—
verses.translation: Surely humankind is ungrateful to their Lord—

verses.text: and they certainly attest to this—
verses.translation: and they certainly attest to this—

verses.text: and they are truly extreme in their love of ˹worldly˺ gains.
verses.translation: and they are truly extreme in their love of ˹worldly˺ gains.

verses.text: Do they not know that when the contents of the graves will be spilled out,
verses.translation: Do they not know that when the contents of the graves will be spilled out,

verses.text: and the secrets of the hearts will be laid bare—
verses.translation: and the secrets of the hearts will be laid bare—

verses.text: surely their Lord is All-Aware of them on that Day. *** -- 559 of 694 --
verses.translation: surely their Lord is All-Aware of them on that Day. *** -- 559 of 694 --

name: The Striking Disaster
intro: This Meccan sûrah describes the Resurrection and the weighing of deeds in the Hereafter, followed by the final destination to either Paradise or Hell. The reason why many people will end up in the Fire is given in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Fate of the Righteous and the Wicked

verses.text: The Striking Disaster!
verses.translation: The Striking Disaster!

verses.text: What is the Striking Disaster?
verses.translation: What is the Striking Disaster?

verses.text: And what will make you realize what the Striking Disaster is?
verses.translation: And what will make you realize what the Striking Disaster is?

verses.text: ˹It is˺ the Day people will be like scattered moths,
verses.translation: ˹It is˺ the Day people will be like scattered moths,

verses.text: and the mountains will be like carded wool.
verses.translation: and the mountains will be like carded wool.

verses.text: So as for those whose scale is heavy ˹with good deeds˺,
verses.translation: So as for those whose scale is heavy ˹with good deeds˺,

verses.text: they will be in a life of bliss.
verses.translation: they will be in a life of bliss.

verses.text: And as for those whose scale is light,
verses.translation: And as for those whose scale is light,

verses.text: their home will be the abyss.
verses.translation: their home will be the abyss.

verses.text: And what will make you realize what that is?
verses.translation: And what will make you realize what that is?

verses.text: ˹It is˺ a scorching Fire. *** -- 560 of 694 --
verses.translation: ˹It is˺ a scorching Fire. *** -- 560 of 694 --

name: Competition for More ˹Gains˺
intro: In this Meccan sûrah and the next, the disbelievers are criticized for wasting their lives doing things that do not matter in the Hereafter, most importantly hoarding wealth. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Wasted Lives

verses.text: Competition for more ˹gains˺ diverts you ˹from Allah˺,
verses.translation: Competition for more ˹gains˺ diverts you ˹from Allah˺,

verses.text: until you end up in ˹your˺ graves.[1326]
verses.translation: until you end up in ˹your˺ graves.[1326]

verses.text: But no! You will soon come to know.
verses.translation: But no! You will soon come to know.

verses.text: Again, no! You will soon come to know.
verses.translation: Again, no! You will soon come to know.

verses.text: Indeed, if you were to know ˹your fate˺ with certainty, ˹you would have acted differently˺.
verses.translation: Indeed, if you were to know ˹your fate˺ with certainty, ˹you would have acted differently˺.

verses.text: ˹But˺ you will surely see the Hellfire.
verses.translation: ˹But˺ you will surely see the Hellfire.

verses.text: Again, you will surely see it with the eye of certainty.
verses.translation: Again, you will surely see it with the eye of certainty.

verses.text: Then, on that Day, you will definitely be questioned about ˹your worldly˺ pleasures. *** -- 561 of 694 --
verses.translation: Then, on that Day, you will definitely be questioned about ˹your worldly˺ pleasures. *** -- 561 of 694 --

name: The ˹Passage of˺ Time
intro: This Meccan sûrah emphasizes that, unlike the evildoers mentioned in the next sûrah, only those who take advantage of this fleeting life by doing good will be successful in the eternal life to come. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Wake-up Call to Humanity

verses.text: By the ˹passage of˺ time!
verses.translation: By the ˹passage of˺ time!

verses.text: Surely humanity is in ˹grave˺ loss,
verses.translation: Surely humanity is in ˹grave˺ loss,

verses.text: except those who have faith, do good, and urge each other to the truth, and urge each other to perseverance. *** -- 562 of 694 --
verses.translation: except those who have faith, do good, and urge each other to the truth, and urge each other to perseverance. *** -- 562 of 694 --

name: The Backbiters
intro: This Meccan sûrah is critical of those who slander others and withhold Allah’s bounties. It is made clear that their punishment in Hell is as easy for Allah as the destruction of the evil force mentioned in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Warning to Defamers

verses.text: Woe to every backbiter, slanderer,
verses.translation: Woe to every backbiter, slanderer,

verses.text: who amasses wealth ˹greedily˺ and counts it ˹repeatedly˺,
verses.translation: who amasses wealth ˹greedily˺ and counts it ˹repeatedly˺,

verses.text: thinking that their wealth will make them immortal!
verses.translation: thinking that their wealth will make them immortal!

verses.text: Not at all! Such a person will certainly be tossed into the Crusher.
verses.translation: Not at all! Such a person will certainly be tossed into the Crusher.

verses.text: And what will make you realize what the Crusher is?
verses.translation: And what will make you realize what the Crusher is?

verses.text: ˹It is˺ Allah’s kindled Fire,
verses.translation: ˹It is˺ Allah’s kindled Fire,

verses.text: which rages over the hearts.
verses.translation: which rages over the hearts.

verses.text: It will be sealed over them,
verses.translation: It will be sealed over them,

verses.text: ˹tightly secured˺ with long braces.[1327] *** -- 563 of 694 --
verses.translation: ˹tightly secured˺ with long braces.[1327] *** -- 563 of 694 --

name: The Elephant
intro: This Meccan sûrah recounts the story of Abraha Al- Ḥabashi (lit., the Abyssinian), who led a large army of men and elephants to demolish the Ka’bah in 570 C.E. so pilgrims would visit the cathedral he had built in Yemen instead. However, the army was destroyed before reaching Mecca. It is commonly believed that the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) was born the same year. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Allah’s Protection of the Ka’bah

verses.text: Have you not seen ˹O Prophet˺ how your Lord dealt with the Army of the Elephant?
verses.translation: Have you not seen ˹O Prophet˺ how your Lord dealt with the Army of the Elephant?

verses.text: Did He not frustrate their scheme?
verses.translation: Did He not frustrate their scheme?

verses.text: For He sent against them flocks of birds,
verses.translation: For He sent against them flocks of birds,

verses.text: that pelted them with stones of baked clay,
verses.translation: that pelted them with stones of baked clay,

verses.text: leaving them like chewed up straw.[1328] *** -- 564 of 694 --
verses.translation: leaving them like chewed up straw.[1328] *** -- 564 of 694 --

name: ˹The People of˺ Quraysh
intro: This Meccan sûrah is viewed as a continuation of the previous one. The general idea is that the Meccan pagans must be grateful and devoted to Allah alone for saving the Ka’bah from the Army of the Elephant. Those who are unfaithful to Allah and unkind to the helpless are criticized in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Allah’s Major Favour to the Meccans[1329]

verses.text: ˹At least˺ for ˹the favour of˺ making Quraysh habitually secure—
verses.translation: ˹At least˺ for ˹the favour of˺ making Quraysh habitually secure—

verses.text: secure in their trading caravan ˹to Yemen˺ in the winter and ˹Syria˺ in the summer—
verses.translation: secure in their trading caravan ˹to Yemen˺ in the winter and ˹Syria˺ in the summer—

verses.text: let them worship the Lord of this ˹Sacred˺ House,
verses.translation: let them worship the Lord of this ˹Sacred˺ House,

verses.text: Who has fed them against hunger and made them secure against fear.[1330] *** -- 565 of 694 --
verses.translation: Who has fed them against hunger and made them secure against fear.[1330] *** -- 565 of 694 --

name: ˹Simplest˺ Aid
intro: This Meccan sûrah, which takes its name from verse 7, condemns the deniers of the Hereafter for their lack of devotion to Allah and lack of compassion towards the needy. In the next sûrah, the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) is ordered to be devoted to Allah alone and share the meat of his sacrificial animals with those in need. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Qualities of Judgment Deniers

verses.text: Have you seen the one who denies the ˹final˺ Judgment?
verses.translation: Have you seen the one who denies the ˹final˺ Judgment?

verses.text: That is the one who repulses the orphan,
verses.translation: That is the one who repulses the orphan,

verses.text: and does not encourage the feeding of the poor.
verses.translation: and does not encourage the feeding of the poor.

verses.text: So woe to those ˹hypocrites˺ who pray
verses.translation: So woe to those ˹hypocrites˺ who pray

verses.text: yet are unmindful of their prayers;
verses.translation: yet are unmindful of their prayers;

verses.text: those who ˹only˺ show off,
verses.translation: those who ˹only˺ show off,

verses.text: and refuse to give ˹even the simplest˺ aid.[1331] *** -- 566 of 694 --
verses.translation: and refuse to give ˹even the simplest˺ aid.[1331] *** -- 566 of 694 --

name: Abundant Goodness
intro: This Meccan sûrah was revealed to reassure the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص). Since the Prophet’s sons died in childhood, Al-’ Ȃṣ ibn Wâ'il, an infamous Meccan pagan, used to say that Mu ḥammad ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) would be forgotten because he had no son to carry his name. Today, ‘Mu ḥammad’ is the most common name in the world, whereas the name of Al-’ Ȃṣ is barely mentioned. The Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) is ordered to be devoted to Allah alone, which is the underlying theme of the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Good News to the Prophet

verses.text: Indeed, We have granted you ˹O Prophet˺ abundant goodness.[1332]
verses.translation: Indeed, We have granted you ˹O Prophet˺ abundant goodness.[1332]

verses.text: So pray and sacrifice to your Lord ˹alone˺.
verses.translation: So pray and sacrifice to your Lord ˹alone˺.

verses.text: Only the one who hates you is truly cut off ˹from any goodness˺. *** -- 567 of 694 --
verses.translation: Only the one who hates you is truly cut off ˹from any goodness˺. *** -- 567 of 694 --

name: The Disbelievers
intro: It is reported that the pagans offered to worship Allah alone for one year, provided that the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) worshipped their multiple gods for a year. So this Meccan sûrah was revealed, telling them that he ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) will be dedicated only to the worship of Allah until the last breath of his life, which is the highlight of the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful No Compromise in Worshipping Allah

verses.text: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “O you disbelievers!
verses.translation: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “O you disbelievers!

verses.text: I do not worship what you worship,
verses.translation: I do not worship what you worship,

verses.text: nor do you worship what I worship.
verses.translation: nor do you worship what I worship.

verses.text: I will never worship what you worship,
verses.translation: I will never worship what you worship,

verses.text: nor will you ever worship what I worship.
verses.translation: nor will you ever worship what I worship.

verses.text: You have your way, and I have my Way.” *** -- 568 of 694 --
verses.translation: You have your way, and I have my Way.” *** -- 568 of 694 --

name: The ˹Ultimate˺ Help
intro: This Medinian sûrah was revealed close to the end of the Prophet’s life, instructing him that once his mission is complete and his message is embraced by many, he ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) should be ready to meet his Creator. A deterring example of those who rejected his message is given in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Nearing the Journey’s End

verses.text: When Allah’s ˹ultimate˺ help comes and the victory ˹over Mecca is achieved˺,
verses.translation: When Allah’s ˹ultimate˺ help comes and the victory ˹over Mecca is achieved˺,

verses.text: and you ˹O Prophet˺ see the people embracing Allah’s Way in crowds,
verses.translation: and you ˹O Prophet˺ see the people embracing Allah’s Way in crowds,

verses.text: then glorify the praises of your Lord and seek His forgiveness, for certainly He is ever Accepting of Repentance. *** -- 569 of 694 --
verses.translation: then glorify the praises of your Lord and seek His forgiveness, for certainly He is ever Accepting of Repentance. *** -- 569 of 694 --

name: The Palm-Fibre Rope
intro: This Meccan sûrah is a warning to Abu Lahab (lit., the Father of Flames), who was an uncle of the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص). Both Abu Lahab and his wife Um Jamîl used to abuse the Prophet ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and deny the One True God, Who is described in the next sûrah. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful The Fate of an Evil Couple

verses.text: May the hands of Abu Lahab perish, and he ˹himself˺ perish!
verses.translation: May the hands of Abu Lahab perish, and he ˹himself˺ perish!

verses.text: Neither his wealth nor ˹worldly˺ gains will benefit him.
verses.translation: Neither his wealth nor ˹worldly˺ gains will benefit him.

verses.text: He will burn in a flaming Fire,
verses.translation: He will burn in a flaming Fire,

verses.text: and ˹so will˺ his wife, the carrier of ˹thorny˺ kindling,[1333]
verses.translation: and ˹so will˺ his wife, the carrier of ˹thorny˺ kindling,[1333]

verses.text: around her neck will be a rope of palm-fibre.[1334] *** -- 570 of 694 --
verses.translation: around her neck will be a rope of palm-fibre.[1334] *** -- 570 of 694 --

name: Purity of Faith
intro: This Meccan sûrah refutes the Trinity, idolatry, atheism, and polytheism and calls for full devotion to the only True God, Who is worthy to be worshipped and Whose protection is to be sought, according to the next two sûrahs. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Allah’s Absolute Oneness

verses.text: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “He is Allah—One ˹and Indivisible˺;
verses.translation: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “He is Allah—One ˹and Indivisible˺;

verses.text: Allah—the Sustainer ˹needed by all˺.
verses.translation: Allah—the Sustainer ˹needed by all˺.

verses.text: He has never had offspring, nor was He born.
verses.translation: He has never had offspring, nor was He born.

verses.text: And there is none comparable to Him.”[1335] *** -- 571 of 694 --
verses.translation: And there is none comparable to Him.”[1335] *** -- 571 of 694 --

name: The Daybreak
intro: This Medinian sûrah is recited as a supplication to the Almighty against any kind of evil. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Seeking Protection Against All Evil

verses.text: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “I seek refuge in the Lord of the daybreak
verses.translation: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “I seek refuge in the Lord of the daybreak

verses.text: from the evil of whatever He has created,
verses.translation: from the evil of whatever He has created,

verses.text: and from the evil of the night when it grows dark,
verses.translation: and from the evil of the night when it grows dark,

verses.text: and from the evil of those ˹witches casting spells by˺ blowing onto knots,
verses.translation: and from the evil of those ˹witches casting spells by˺ blowing onto knots,

verses.text: and from the evil of an envier when they envy.” *** -- 572 of 694 --
verses.translation: and from the evil of an envier when they envy.” *** -- 572 of 694 --

name: Humankind
intro: Like the previous sûrah, this Medinian sûrah is a supplication against the evil of humans and jinn. This final sûrah emphasizes the fact that Allah is the Lord and Master of all and that He is the only One to be called upon for help, which connects full circle with the central theme of the first sûrah of the Quran. In the Name of Allah—the Most Compassionate, Most Merciful Seeking Protection Against Evil Whispers

verses.text: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “I seek refuge in the Lord of humankind,
verses.translation: Say, ˹O Prophet,˺ “I seek refuge in the Lord of humankind,

verses.text: the Master of humankind,
verses.translation: the Master of humankind,

verses.text: the God of humankind,
verses.translation: the God of humankind,

verses.text: from the evil of the lurking whisperer—
verses.translation: from the evil of the lurking whisperer—

verses.text: who whispers into the hearts of humankind—
verses.translation: who whispers into the hearts of humankind—

verses.text: *** COMMON QUESTIONS ABOUT ISLAM What Is Islam? Islam did not start with Prophet Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) in the 7th century. Technically, Islam is the message that was delivered by all the prophets of Allah from Adam (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) to Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص). Islam is neither named after a person or a tribe nor does it end with an –ism. Though each prophet had a relatively different law, the essence of the message of Islam was always the same: have faith in one God and do good. In the Bible, the first four of the Ten Commandments enjoin the worship of one God; the rest urge believers to avoid what is wrong and to do what is good. All prophets and their followers (including Jesus and his disciples) are simply called “Muslims” in the Quran. Hence, anyone who submits to Allah and strives to be a good person can be called a ‘muslim’ (with a small ‘m’) from a linguistic perspective. Every human being is born with the innate will (fi ṭrah) to submit to Allah, but parents and society change this nature, and in order to relate to the Almighty, many have put a face on God (mostly human or animal) throughout history. The process of restoring the fi ṭrah is called reversion. Islam is not only a religion, but a comprehensive way of life. Based on common sense and clear-cut teachings, Islam defines the rights and responsibilities of every individual in regards to their relationship with Allah and His creation. It balances the spiritual and material needs of its followers and helps them gain happiness in this life and salvation in the next. Who Is a Muslim? A ‘Muslim’ (with a capital ‘M’) is someone who practices Islam. Muslims follow the five pillars of Islam: -Shahâdah, testifying that there is only One God and Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) is His last Prophet - Ṣalâh, praying five times a day - Ṣawm, fasting from dawn to sunset during the month of Ramaḍân -Zakâh, paying alms-tax on savings worth 85 g of gold or more, if the amount is kept for a year - Ḥajj, performing pilgrimage to Mecca, if physically and financially able to. Muslims also believe in the six articles of faith: -Almighty Allah -His angels -His prophets -His scriptures -Free choice, fate, and destiny -The Day of Judgment Islam is the fastest growing religion in the world. Totalling 1.6 billion, Muslims make up one-quarter of the world’s population. Muslims come from different ethnic, cultural, and social backgrounds. Contrary to the common belief, not all Muslims are Arab; not all Arabs are Muslim. Arabs make up less than 18% of the world’s Muslim population. Indonesia (a single non-Arab Muslim country in Southeast Asia) has more Muslims than all Arab countries combined. Islam should not be judged by what any Muslim does, but Muslims should be judged based on what Islam teaches. Islam is perfect; Muslims are not. Who Is Prophet Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص)? The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) was born in Mecca in the year 570 C.E. His father died before his birth and his mother died when he was six years old. As he grew up, he acquired the epithet ‘the trustworthy.’ Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) had long detested the idolatry, social injustice, and corruption found in society. At the age of forty, he (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) received the first revelation of the Quran from Allah through the angel Gabriel. Since the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) could not read or write, he had scribes write down passages over the course of their revelation. The Quran was also memorized word for word by the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and many of his companions. Although the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) performed many miracles, such as the splitting of the moon (see ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص 54:1), water gushing out from between his fingers, multiplying food, still the Quran is his greatest miracle. Just like many previous prophets, Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and his early followers were persecuted—and some were even killed—for advocating revolutionary ideas such as social justice and women’s rights. As the persecution grew fierce, the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and many of his companions emigrated to the city of Medina, 260 miles to the north of Mecca. This emigration (Hijrah) marks the beginning of the Muslim calendar. After several years, Mecca ultimately surrendered peacefully to Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) who issued a universal amnesty. Before the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) passed away at the age of sixty-three, the greater part of the Arabian Peninsula had become Muslim, and within a century of his death, Islam had spread to Spain in the west and as far east as China. The rapid spread of Islam (especially to territories previously occupied by the Byzantine and Persian empires) was mostly because of its simple teachings and social justice. Why Do Muslims Call God ‘Allah’? Arab Muslims, Christians, and Jews call God ‘Allah.’ The word ‘Allah’ is unique in the sense that it has no plural or gender. It literally means in Arabic “the One, True God.” Allah has many attributes and beautiful names such as the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, the All-Loving, the Judge, the Creator, and the Provider. In his native tongue of Aramaic, Jesus (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) used Alaha to refer to Allah. Moses (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) used, among other things, Eloh in Hebrew. Allah, Alaha, and Eloh come from three Semitic languages: Arabic, Aramaic, and Hebrew respectively. What Is the Quran? The Quran is the holy book of Islam. It is a collection of revelations that were received by the Prophet Muhammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) over the course of twenty-three years in the 7th century C.E. There is only one version of the Quran, perfectly preserved in written and oral records around the world for nearly 1400 years. The Quran is the only book in history that has been memorized verbatim by millions of people. Sûrahs were written down separately during ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص the life of the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and were collected in one volume within two years of his death. Exact copies were later duplicated from the original collection during the reign of the 3rd Caliph, ’Uthmân ibn ’Affân, and sent to major Muslim cities. Today, all copies of the Quran (called ma ṣâḥif, plural of mu ṣḥaf) are perfect duplicates of the original. The Quran emphasizes universal ethics such as honesty, sincerity, generosity, mercy, and standing up for what is right. It aims at humanizing humanity and deifying Allah and therefore condemns those who personify Allah and idolize their fellow created beings. Was the Quran Copied from the Bible? It is worth mentioning that the first Arabic translation of the Bible was done centuries after the Prophet’s death. From an Islamic point of view, similarities between the Quran and the Bible (especially historical stories such as that of Joseph, Moses, and Jesus) stem from the fact that both scriptures came originally from the same source—divine revelation. Because of differences in transmission and interpretation of the Bible, over time the stories changed. The Quranic narratives now appear slightly different, for example, unlike the Quran (20:120-122), in the book of Genesis, Eve was tempted to eat from the tree and therefore she is to blame for the Fall. Also, according to the Quran (Sûrah 19), prophets are infallible of sin. But in the Bible, some prophets are guilty of shameful and even criminal acts. For example, David impregnated his neighbour’s wife (Bathsheba) before conspiring to get her husband (Uriah) killed (II Samuel 11:1-27), Lot had sex with his two daughters (Genesis 19:30-38), and Noah got drunk and naked (Genesis 9:20-21). Some Biblical stories are not in the Quran and vice versa. For example, the Biblical story of Isaiah is not in the Quran, while the story of Moses and Al-Khaḍir mentioned in Sûrah 18 of the Quran is not in the Bible. Also, there are three miracles of Jesus in the Quran that are not in the Bible (see 5:110-115). Although both scriptures emphasize global ethics (such as dignity, kindness, and charity), each revolves around a different theology. Both have contrasting views on the perception of Allah, Jesus, salvation, crucifixion, and the original sin. Is Islam Compatible with Science? Although the Quran is a book of signs, not a book of science, there are many scientific references in the Quran such as the formation and developmental phases of an embryo in the uterus (23:12–14 and 22:5), the Big Bang (21:30), the constant expansion of the universe (51:47–8), spherical shape of the earth (39:5 and 79:30), the earth’s rotation (27:88), and many others that have become known only in the last two centuries. According to an Arab proverb, “The ink of a scholar is holier than the blood of a martyr.” Islam’s emphasis on education galvanized learning and science in the Muslim world culminating in what is known as the Islamic Golden Age. For centuries, Muslims pioneered medicine, anatomy, mathematics, geography, astronomy, architecture, and many other sciences. Algebra, alchemy, and alcohol are all Arabic words. The Canon of Medicine by Avicenna (Ibn Sina, 980-1037 C.E.) was a primary medical text in medieval Europe for more than 700 years. Many surgical tools that are in use today were invented by Albucasis (Alzahrâwi, 936-1013 C.E.). Mariam Al-Astrolabiya, a female Muslim scholar who lived in the 10th century in Syria, was famous for designing and constructing astrolabes. Arabic numerals (0, 1, 2, 3, etc.) are used worldwide. Muslims invented numerous sciences and developed many others (which they had inherited from the Romans, Greeks, Persians, Indians, and others) and laid the foundations to the European industrial revolution. The invention of cameras, computers, and navigation systems could not have been possible without the contributions of Muslim scholars. What Is Sharia Law? Linguistically, Sharia means a pathway. Technically, it is the Muslim law, derived mainly from the Quran and the teachings of Prophet Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص), governing every aspect of a Muslim’s life. Sharia is made up of thousands of teachings and rulings covering theology, acts of worship, manners, human interactions, business transactions, family relations (marriage, divorce, inheritance, etc.), war and peace, belief in the unseen (Allah, angels, and the Hereafter), and criminal law. Sharia mainly aims at protecting 5 things: 1) Life 2) Honour 3) Freedom to practice one’s faith 4) Intellect 5) Property. Therefore, there are punishments in Islamic Law for violating any of these rights. Every country has punishments for offences—even though the penalty for the same crime may vary from one country to another. To say that Sharia is all about chopping people’s hands off is like saying that the American law is all about killing people with the electric chair! Sharia does not apply to non- Muslim minorities living in predominantly Muslim countries. Of the fifty- seven Muslim countries in the world, the great majority are secular, not Sharia-based. Muslims living in the West follow the law of the land and maintain Sharia mainly in personal matters (such as prayers, marriage, and inheritance). Sharia also forbids the consumption of pork, alcohol, and drugs. Smoking is frowned upon. Is Islam Compatible with Modern Democracy? We have to make the distinction between what Islam teaches and how countries in the Muslim world are run. As pointed out earlier, many Muslim countries are secular-based, not fully subscribing to Islamic morals or western democratic values. Islam and modern democracies have many things in common. For example, the fundamental principles in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights are acceptable Islamically. What makes Islamic values unique is that they do not change over time, what is right in the sight of Allah is always right and what is wrong is always wrong. On the other hand, many secular freedoms (which have been mostly adopted in the last few decades) are still subject to debate in western societies. For example, marijuana, same-sex marriage, abortion, incest, and prostitution are legal in some democracies and illegal in some others. The same applies to euthanasia and the death penalty. Moreover, in a secular society, the majority’s opinion prevails. In the Islamic concept of shûra, the truth prevails even if it is held by a minority. For example, the segregation of blacks and whites under the Jim Crow Laws would be prohibited under Sharia, since discrimination based on colour goes against Islamic beliefs. Does Jihad Equal Terrorism? Life is sacred in Islam. The Quran (5:32) states, “Whoever takes a life …, it will be as if they killed all of humanity; and whoever saves a life, it will be as if they saved all of humanity.” Those who manipulate verses from the Quran by taking them out of context to justify violence against innocents contradict the Quran’s call for tolerance and peaceful co-existence. Islam is unequivocally against terrorism (see 5:33). Jihad means to strive for a better, more righteous life. The major jihad is to overcome one’s desires (such as greed). Prophet Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) says, “The highest form of jihad is to speak a word of truth in the presence of a tyrant,” “Kindness to parents is a form of jihad,” and “Charity to orphans and widows is jihad.” The minor jihad is fighting in self-defence. The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) set the etiquettes of fighting as follows: “Do not ask Allah to meet your enemies in battle” and “Do not start a war. If you must fight, then strike only at those ˹combatants˺ who attacked you. Do not attack women, children, the elderly, or those retreating in their places of worship. Do not cut down trees or kill animals.” We have to keep in mind that all violent passages in the Quran (including verses in sûrahs 2, 8, 9, 47, and 48) strictly concern conflicts between early Muslims and the pagans of Mecca over 1400 years ago. As such, all passages should be understood in their historical context. In Islam, fighting is allowed against aggressors regardless of their faith. Fighting against innocents is prohibited regardless of their faith. Overall, violent passages in the Quran talk about one of three things: -Fighting back in self-defence. -Making peace if attackers cease. -Or resuming the fight if a truce is violated. What is the Origin of Religious Violence? No religion condones the killing of innocents, but some people manipulate religion to justify acts of violence. So, even if Islam and other faiths have never existed, humans would have come up with other excuses to fight for domination. We have seen notorious anti-religion, secularist ideologies, like those championed by Mao and Stalin (the top mass murderers in modern history), which were responsible for over seventy million deaths in the 20th century. Most victims of violence in the Muslim world are Muslims, who are either killed by unjustified wars, suicide bombs, or drone attacks. Over the last few decades, hundreds of thousands have been killed—most of them civilians—and many others wounded or displaced. Justice, dignity, and education, some of the most fundamental aspects of human rights, are the key to peace and prosperity anywhere in the world. Are Women Abused in Islam? The Quran makes it clear that men and women are equal before Allah and the Law (16:97 and 33:35). Abuses against some Muslim women (e.g., honour killing and forced marriages) are cultural practices in some Muslim countries that contradict Islamic teachings. There are many prominent Muslim women in every field: education, science, business, etc. Several Muslim women have been elected president and prime minister in Muslim-majority countries like Indonesia, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Turkey. The high status of women in Islam explains why 75% of reverts to Islam are women. Why Do Muslim Women Wear the Hijab? The veil is deeply rooted in all Abrahamic traditions. Christian icons such as Mary and Mother Teresa are always depicted with veils. In the Quran and the teachings of the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص), both men and women are urged to be modest in their dress and behaviour. Hijab is worn by adult Muslim women in the presence of adult males outside of their immediate family. What Are the Rights of Non-Muslims in Islam? Islam guarantees the freedom of non-Muslims to practice their faith and protection for their places of worship. The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) said, “Whoever harms a non-Muslim under the protection of Islam, I shall be their opponent on Judgment Day and they will not even smell Paradise.” The Quran teaches that there are three types of brotherhood: brotherhood in humanity (this includes all human beings), biological brotherhood (one’s siblings), and brotherhood in faith (fellow Muslims). Islam allows giving charity to non-Muslims and exchanging gifts and visits with them. The Quran (60:8-9) exhorts Muslims to be kind and generous to non-Muslims. It forbids forcing non-Muslims to convert to Islam (2:256). For centuries, non-Muslim communities thrived under Muslim rule. Many Christians and Jews occupied prominent positions in the courts of some Muslim caliphs, serving as translators, physicians, and architects. Do Muslims Believe in Other Prophets? The Quran mentions twenty-five prophets by name—of whom five are given the honorary title of ‘the Messengers of Firm Resolve,’ namely Abraham, Noah, Moses, Jesus, and Muḥammad. The Quran (12:111) says, “In their stories there is truly a lesson for people of reason.” Some of the most common names in the Muslim world include ’Îsa (Jesus in Arabic), Mûsa (Moses), Mariam (Mary), Yûsuf (Joseph), and Ibrâhîm (Abraham). Jesus is mentioned by name in the Quran twenty-five times, Mary thirty- one times (compared to eighteen times in the Bible), whereas Prophet Muḥammad is mentioned by name only four times. Sûrah 19 of the Quran is named after Mary. Muslims believe that Jesus is the Christ and the Messiah. They also believe in his virgin birth, ascension, and second coming. Just like many previous prophets, Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and his early followers were persecuted—and some were even killed—for advocating revolutionary ideas such as social justice and women’s rights. As the persecution grew fierce, the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and many of his companions emigrated to the city of Medina, 260 miles to the north of Mecca. This emigration (Hijrah) marks the beginning of the Muslim calendar. After several years, Mecca ultimately surrendered peacefully to Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) who issued a universal amnesty. Before the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) passed away at the age of sixty-three, the greater part of the Arabian Peninsula had become Muslim, and within a century of his death, Islam had spread to Spain in the west and as far east as China. The rapid spread of Islam (especially to territories previously occupied by the Byzantine and Persian empires) was mostly because of its simple teachings and social justice. Why Do Muslims Call God ‘Allah’? Arab Muslims, Christians, and Jews call God ‘Allah.’ The word ‘Allah’ is unique in the sense that it has no plural or gender. It literally means in Arabic “the One, True God.” Allah has many attributes and beautiful names such as the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, the All-Loving, the Judge, the Creator, and the Provider. In his native tongue of Aramaic, Jesus (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) used Alaha to refer to Allah. Moses (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) used, among other things, Eloh in Hebrew. Allah, Alaha, and Eloh come from three Semitic languages: Arabic, Aramaic, and Hebrew respectively. What Is the Quran? The Quran is the holy book of Islam. It is a collection of revelations that were received by the Prophet Muhammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) over the course of twenty-three years in the 7th century C.E. There is only one version of the Quran, perfectly preserved in written and oral records around the world for nearly 1400 years. The Quran is the only book in history that has been memorized verbatim by millions of people. Sûrahs were written down separately during ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص the life of the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) and were collected in one volume within two years of his death. Exact copies were later duplicated from the original collection during the reign of the 3rd Caliph, ’Uthmân ibn ’Affân, and sent to major Muslim cities. Today, all copies of the Quran (called ma ṣâḥif, plural of mu ṣḥaf) are perfect duplicates of the original. The Quran emphasizes universal ethics such as honesty, sincerity, generosity, mercy, and standing up for what is right. It aims at humanizing humanity and deifying Allah and therefore condemns those who personify Allah and idolize their fellow created beings. Was the Quran Copied from the Bible? It is worth mentioning that the first Arabic translation of the Bible was done centuries after the Prophet’s death. From an Islamic point of view, similarities between the Quran and the Bible (especially historical stories such as that of Joseph, Moses, and Jesus) stem from the fact that both scriptures came originally from the same source—divine revelation. Because of differences in transmission and interpretation of the Bible, over time the stories changed. The Quranic narratives now appear slightly different, for example, unlike the Quran (20:120-122), in the book of Genesis, Eve was tempted to eat from the tree and therefore she is to blame for the Fall. Also, according to the Quran (Sûrah 19), prophets are infallible of sin. But in the Bible, some prophets are guilty of shameful and even criminal acts. For example, David impregnated his neighbour’s wife (Bathsheba) before conspiring to get her husband (Uriah) killed (II Samuel 11:1-27), Lot had sex with his two daughters (Genesis 19:30-38), and Noah got drunk and naked (Genesis 9:20-21). Some Biblical stories are not in the Quran and vice versa. For example, the Biblical story of Isaiah is not in the Quran, while the story of Moses and Al-Khaḍir mentioned in Sûrah 18 of the Quran is not in the Bible. Also, there are three miracles of Jesus in the Quran that are not in the Bible (see 5:110-115). Although both scriptures emphasize global ethics (such as dignity, kindness, and charity), each revolves around a different theology. Both have contrasting views on the perception of Allah, Jesus, salvation, crucifixion, and the original sin. Is Islam Compatible with Science? Although the Quran is a book of signs, not a book of science, there are many scientific references in the Quran such as the formation and developmental phases of an embryo in the uterus (23:12–14 and 22:5), the Big Bang (21:30), the constant expansion of the universe (51:47–8), spherical shape of the earth (39:5 and 79:30), the earth’s rotation (27:88), and many others that have become known only in the last two centuries. According to an Arab proverb, “The ink of a scholar is holier than the blood of a martyr.” Islam’s emphasis on education galvanized learning and science in the Muslim world culminating in what is known as the Islamic Golden Age. For centuries, Muslims pioneered medicine, anatomy, mathematics, geography, astronomy, architecture, and many other sciences. Algebra, alchemy, and alcohol are all Arabic words. The Canon of Medicine by Avicenna (Ibn Sina, 980-1037 C.E.) was a primary medical text in medieval Europe for more than 700 years. Many surgical tools that are in use today were invented by Albucasis (Alzahrâwi, 936-1013 C.E.). Mariam Al-Astrolabiya, a female Muslim scholar who lived in the 10th century in Syria, was famous for designing and constructing astrolabes. Arabic numerals (0, 1, 2, 3, etc.) are used worldwide. Muslims invented numerous sciences and developed many others (which they had inherited from the Romans, Greeks, Persians, Indians, and others) and laid the foundations to the European industrial revolution. The invention of cameras, computers, and navigation systems could not have been possible without the contributions of Muslim scholars. What Is Sharia Law? Linguistically, Sharia means a pathway. Technically, it is the Muslim law, derived mainly from the Quran and the teachings of Prophet Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص), governing every aspect of a Muslim’s life. Sharia is made up of thousands of teachings and rulings covering theology, acts of worship, manners, human interactions, business transactions, family relations (marriage, divorce, inheritance, etc.), war and peace, belief in the unseen (Allah, angels, and the Hereafter), and criminal law. Sharia mainly aims at protecting 5 things: 1) Life 2) Honour 3) Freedom to practice one’s faith 4) Intellect 5) Property. Therefore, there are punishments in Islamic Law for violating any of these rights. Every country has punishments for offences—even though the penalty for the same crime may vary from one country to another. To say that Sharia is all about chopping people’s hands off is like saying that the American law is all about killing people with the electric chair! Sharia does not apply to non- Muslim minorities living in predominantly Muslim countries. Of the fifty- seven Muslim countries in the world, the great majority are secular, not Sharia-based. Muslims living in the West follow the law of the land and maintain Sharia mainly in personal matters (such as prayers, marriage, and inheritance). Sharia also forbids the consumption of pork, alcohol, and drugs. Smoking is frowned upon. Is Islam Compatible with Modern Democracy? We have to make the distinction between what Islam teaches and how countries in the Muslim world are run. As pointed out earlier, many Muslim countries are secular-based, not fully subscribing to Islamic morals or western democratic values. Islam and modern democracies have many things in common. For example, the fundamental principles in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights are acceptable Islamically. What makes Islamic values unique is that they do not change over time, what is right in the sight of Allah is always right and what is wrong is always wrong. On the other hand, many secular freedoms (which have been mostly adopted in the last few decades) are still subject to debate in western societies. For example, marijuana, same-sex marriage, abortion, incest, and prostitution are legal in some democracies and illegal in some others. The same applies to euthanasia and the death penalty. Moreover, in a secular society, the majority’s opinion prevails. In the Islamic concept of shûra, the truth prevails even if it is held by a minority. For example, the segregation of blacks and whites under the Jim Crow Laws would be prohibited under Sharia, since discrimination based on colour goes against Islamic beliefs. Does Jihad Equal Terrorism? Life is sacred in Islam. The Quran (5:32) states, “Whoever takes a life …, it will be as if they killed all of humanity; and whoever saves a life, it will be as if they saved all of humanity.” Those who manipulate verses from the Quran by taking them out of context to justify violence against innocents contradict the Quran’s call for tolerance and peaceful co-existence. Islam is unequivocally against terrorism (see 5:33). Jihad means to strive for a better, more righteous life. The major jihad is to overcome one’s desires (such as greed). Prophet Muḥammad (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) says, “The highest form of jihad is to speak a word of truth in the presence of a tyrant,” “Kindness to parents is a form of jihad,” and “Charity to orphans and widows is jihad.” The minor jihad is fighting in self-defence. The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) set the etiquettes of fighting as follows: “Do not ask Allah to meet your enemies in battle” and “Do not start a war. If you must fight, then strike only at those ˹combatants˺ who attacked you. Do not attack women, children, the elderly, or those retreating in their places of worship. Do not cut down trees or kill animals.” We have to keep in mind that all violent passages in the Quran (including verses in sûrahs 2, 8, 9, 47, and 48) strictly concern conflicts between early Muslims and the pagans of Mecca over 1400 years ago. As such, all passages should be understood in their historical context. In Islam, fighting is allowed against aggressors regardless of their faith. Fighting against innocents is prohibited regardless of their faith. Overall, violent passages in the Quran talk about one of three things: -Fighting back in self-defence. -Making peace if attackers cease. -Or resuming the fight if a truce is violated. What is the Origin of Religious Violence? No religion condones the killing of innocents, but some people manipulate religion to justify acts of violence. So, even if Islam and other faiths have never existed, humans would have come up with other excuses to fight for domination. We have seen notorious anti-religion, secularist ideologies, like those championed by Mao and Stalin (the top mass murderers in modern history), which were responsible for over seventy million deaths in the 20th century. Most victims of violence in the Muslim world are Muslims, who are either killed by unjustified wars, suicide bombs, or drone attacks. Over the last few decades, hundreds of thousands have been killed—most of them civilians—and many others wounded or displaced. Justice, dignity, and education, some of the most fundamental aspects of human rights, are the key to peace and prosperity anywhere in the world. Are Women Abused in Islam? The Quran makes it clear that men and women are equal before Allah and the Law (16:97 and 33:35). Abuses against some Muslim women (e.g., honour killing and forced marriages) are cultural practices in some Muslim countries that contradict Islamic teachings. There are many prominent Muslim women in every field: education, science, business, etc. Several Muslim women have been elected president and prime minister in Muslim-majority countries like Indonesia, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Turkey. The high status of women in Islam explains why 75% of reverts to Islam are women. Why Do Muslim Women Wear the Hijab? The veil is deeply rooted in all Abrahamic traditions. Christian icons such as Mary and Mother Teresa are always depicted with veils. In the Quran and the teachings of the Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص), both men and women are urged to be modest in their dress and behaviour. Hijab is worn by adult Muslim women in the presence of adult males outside of their immediate family. What Are the Rights of Non-Muslims in Islam? Islam guarantees the freedom of non-Muslims to practice their faith and protection for their places of worship. The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) said, “Whoever harms a non-Muslim under the protection of Islam, I shall be their opponent on Judgment Day and they will not even smell Paradise.” The Quran teaches that there are three types of brotherhood: brotherhood in humanity (this includes all human beings), biological brotherhood (one’s siblings), and brotherhood in faith (fellow Muslims). Islam allows giving charity to non-Muslims and exchanging gifts and visits with them. The Quran (60:8-9) exhorts Muslims to be kind and generous to non-Muslims. It forbids forcing non-Muslims to convert to Islam (2:256). For centuries, non-Muslim communities thrived under Muslim rule. Many Christians and Jews occupied prominent positions in the courts of some Muslim caliphs, serving as translators, physicians, and architects. Do Muslims Believe in Other Prophets? The Quran mentions twenty-five prophets by name—of whom five are given the honorary title of ‘the Messengers of Firm Resolve,’ namely Abraham, Noah, Moses, Jesus, and Muḥammad. The Quran (12:111) says, “In their stories there is truly a lesson for people of reason.” Some of the most common names in the Muslim world include ’Îsa (Jesus in Arabic), Mûsa (Moses), Mariam (Mary), Yûsuf (Joseph), and Ibrâhîm (Abraham). Jesus is mentioned by name in the Quran twenty-five times, Mary thirty- one times (compared to eighteen times in the Bible), whereas Prophet Muḥammad is mentioned by name only four times. Sûrah 19 of the Quran is named after Mary. Muslims believe that Jesus is the Christ and the Messiah. They also believe in his virgin birth, ascension, and second coming. verses.text: Ⱬul-Kifl … Ⱬul-Kifl As the Quran teaches Muslims not to exalt one prophet over others (2:285), it is customary to say ( ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص ) “peace be upon him” when the name of any of the prophets is mentioned. *** SELECT TEACHINGS OF THE PROPHET MUḤAMMAD (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) On the Environment and Animal Rights “If Judgment Day arrives and you have a seedling in your hand, plant it regardless” and “Don’t waste water even if you live by a river.” The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) prohibited polluting water sources and promised a heavenly reward for planting trees to feed animals, birds, and humans. He taught that a good deed done to an animal is like a good deed done to a human being, while an act of cruelty to an animal is as bad as cruelty to a human being. He prohibited the use of live birds and animals as a target for arrows, the killing of animals for sport, slaughtering an animal in front of other animals, and forbade overburdening animals and underfeeding them. On the Treatment of Others The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) said that smiling is a charity and taught: “They are not of us, those who do not show respect to our seniors or show mercy to our youngsters.” He gave women the right to inheritance, education, to own property, and have a say in marriage and said, “The best among the believers are those who are best to their wives,” and that Paradise lies under the feet of the mother. He (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) received Christians in his mosque and allowed them to pray there when the time for their prayers came. He also commemorated the day Moses and the Children of Israel were saved from Pharaoh and his army by fasting and ordering Muslims to fast—a practice that has continued until today. He (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) said, “O humanity! Your Lord is one and your ancestry [i.e., Adam and Eve] is one. No Arab is superior to a non-Arab and no non- Arab is superior to an Arab, nor is any white superior to any black or any black superior to any white except on account of their piety,” and “None of you truly believes until they love for others what they love for themselves.” On the Best Way of Life ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص The Prophet (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) set out a way of life through his own example, but he also had the following to say on living a fulfilling life. “The ˹true˺ Muslim is the one who does not harm people with his hands or tongue.” “Seeking knowledge is an obligation on every Muslim.” “Don’t respond to evil by evil, but by doing what is good.” “Show mercy to those on earth and Allah will show mercy to you.” “Take advantage of five matters before the coming of five things: your health before you fall sick, your wealth before you become poor, your free time before you become busy, your youth before you become old, and your life before your death.” “Be mindful of Allah and He will always be with you. Remember Allah in times of prosperity and He will remember you in times of adversity. And know that what has passed you by [and you have failed to attain] was not going to befall you, and what has befallen you was not going to pass you by. And know that victory comes with perseverance, relief with affliction, and ease with hardship.” *** WHAT THEY SAID ABOUT MUḤAMMAD (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص) “My choice of Muḥammad to lead the list of the world's most influential persons may surprise some readers and may be questioned by others, but he was the only man in history who was supremely successful on both the religious and secular levels.” --Michael H. Hart, The 100: A Ranking of the Most Influential Persons in History, New York, 1978, p.

verses.text: [12] If you are true that Allah will never create anyone who is more honourable and knowledgeable than you. [13] Prostration in this verse does not mean worship, but an act of respect. A similar occurrence can be found in Sûrah 12, where Jacob (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص), his wife, and his eleven children knelt down before Joseph (ملسو هيلع هللا ىلص). [14] Iblîs was the name of Satan before his fall from grace. Iblîs was not an angel, but one of the jinn (see 18:50). Jinn are another creation of Allah, similar to humans in that they—unlike angels—have free will, but are made of smokeless fire and live in another plane of existence. [15] The command to prostrate was a test of obedience. Satan arrogantly refused to comply because he believed he was superior to Adam—arguing that Adam was made of mud while Satan was made of fire (see 7:12). [16] Both Adam and Eve were deceived, both sinned, and both were later forgiven. There is no concept of original sin in Islam. [17] i.e., humans and Satan. [18] The prayer that Adam and Eve were inspired to say is mentioned in 7:23, “Our Lord! We have wronged ourselves. If You do not forgive us and have mercy on us, we will certainly be losers.” [19] Israel is another name for Prophet Jacob. [20] This refers to the passages in the Torah and the Gospel that call for the worship of the One True God, doing what is good, and avoiding what is evil. [21] Trading Allah’s revelations for a fleeting gain is a recurring theme in the first few sûrahs of the Quran. This refers to the practice of some Jewish authorities in Medina who contradicted certain rulings in the Torah by giving people lenient opinions only to please them in exchange for money.
